The performances of the optimal La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N sample and other typical iron-based cathode materials are compared using Ashby and Lagoon plots (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5i</span></span></a><strong>,</strong> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">j</span></span></a>). La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N has an operating voltage of 3.1 V and a reversible capacity of 128.2 mAh g<sup>-1</sup> at 0.2 C, with an energy density of ∼390 Wh kg<sup>-1</sup>. Compared to the other typical iron-based cathode materials, La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N shows more excellent energy density (<strong>Table S16</strong>) and power density (<strong>Table S17, S18</strong>), indicating its great potential for large-scale energy storage.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0022">The sodium storage mechanism of the La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N sample is analyzed by <em>in-situ</em> XRD, <em>ex-situ</em> EIS, and DFT. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0006" name="bfig0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6a</span></span></a> shows the <em>in-situ</em> XRD volcano map with more distinct diffraction peaks observed near 28.6°, 32.1°, 33.6°, 33.7°, and 34.2°, which correspond to the (013), (022), (004), (222), and (602) crystallographic planes of NFPP, respectively. No new diffraction peaks appear throughout the process, indicating that the material involves only single-phase reactions during charging and discharging. In particular, regular variations of the three types of diffraction peaks are observed (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0006" name="bfig0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6b</span></span></a><strong>,</strong> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0006" name="bfig0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">c</span></span></a>). The diffraction peaks near 27.3° ((020) crystal plane) and 32.1° ((022) crystal plane) exhibit a gradual rightward deviation during charging, followed by a subsequent gradual restoration to their original positions during discharging, which can be attributed to lattice contraction/ expansion during the sodium ion detachment/embedding process. The diffraction peak at 28.6° ((013) crystal plane) is observed to experience a sudden decrease of the peak intensity at 3.2 V voltage. This phenomenon can be explained by the distortion of the [P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>] unit that occurs when half of the Na<sup>+</sup> ions in the Na1 site, together with half of the Na<sup>+</sup> ions in the Na3 site, become delocalized in the NFPP-based material. This distortion effectively buffers the electrostatic repulsion between the Fe1 site and the Fe3 site, allowing the movement of the Fe1 site in the a-axis and resulting in small abrupt changes in both the a- and c-axis lattice parameters [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0027" name="bbib0027" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0027"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a>]. The diffraction peaks at 33.6° ((004) crystallographic plane) and 33.7° ((222) crystallographic plane) are close to each other and almost coincide in the low-pressure state, but separate from each other at a larger angle in the high-pressure state. Thus, the above evidence suggests that the extraction and insertion of Na<sup>+</sup> in La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N is an incomplete solid-solution reaction. It is noteworthy that the volume change of La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N is only 2.44 % throughout the charge/discharge process, which is significantly lower than the reported NFPP electrodes (&gt;4 %). This further confirms the excellent cyclic stability of dual-site defects engineered La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N. In contrast, the <em>in-situ</em> XRD spectra of NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N show a split peak at 33.5°, indicating an unsatisfactory solid solution reaction with poor reversibility (<strong>Figure S17</strong>).</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0006"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724006743-gr6.jpg" height="618" alt="Fig 6" aria-describedby="cap0006"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724006743-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (2MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724006743-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0006"><p id="spara006"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. Sodium storage mechanism analysis. a) <em>In-situ</em> X-ray diffraction volcano map; b) Localized magnification of <em>in-situ</em> X-ray diffraction at 30.0–35.0°; c) Plots of <em>in-situ</em> lattice parameters and cell volume variations; d) Voltage sampling points of <em>ex-situ</em> impedance; e) <em>Ex-situ</em> impedance plots; f) <em>R</em><sub>ct</sub> values calculated from <em>ex-situ</em> impedance.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0023">The <em>ex-situ</em> EIS spectra of La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0006" name="bfig0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6d</span></span></a><strong>–</strong><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0006" name="bfig0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">f</span></span></a>. Throughout the charging and discharging process, a regular decrease in charge transfer resistance (<em>R</em><sub>ct</sub>) with increasing voltage is observed. This can be attributed to the lattice contraction of the NFPP-based material in the deliquescent state (oxidation state), the thinner SEI due to partial decomposition, and an increase in electronic conductivity. Subsequently the charge transfer resistance (<em>R</em><sub>ct</sub>) increases regularly with decreasing voltage, due to the expansion of the lattice of the NFPP-based material in the embedded sodium state (reduced state), the thickening of the SEI deposition, and the decrease of the electronic conductivity. In particular, the slow variation of the charge transfer resistance (<em>R</em><sub>ct</sub>) at 2.8–3.2 V corresponds to the embedding/de-embedding process of a large amount of Na<sup>+</sup> in the lattice when the voltage is in the plateau interval. In contrast, a sharp change of charge transfer resistance (<em>R</em><sub>ct</sub>) in the voltage ramp interval corresponds to the Na<sup>+</sup> deposition/consumption process in the SEI.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0024">The effect of dual-site defects engineering on the modification of NFPP and the defects formation energy are calculated by DFT (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0007" name="bfig0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>). The Projected Density of State (PDOS) (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0007" name="bfig0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7a</span></span></a><strong>,</strong> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0007" name="bfig0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">b</span></span></a>) show that both NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N and La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N exhibit semiconducting properties, and the optimal sample, dual-site defects engineered La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N, exhibits stronger metallic properties overall with a band gap of about 2.1 eV, which is much smaller than that of 3.6 eV for NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N, indicating that the dual-site defects engineering treatment enhance the electronically conductivity. The contributions to the overall energy band densities of NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N and La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N mainly originate from the p orbitals of Fe and the s orbitals of O. The s orbitals of O in La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N are interlocked with the p orbitals of Fe, the s orbitals of Na, the p orbitals of P, the d orbitals of La, and the P orbitals of Br, respectively, at different energy level distributions, which indicates that La and Br are bonded to O inside the lattice. The energy band density of La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N near the Fermi energy level is significantly higher than that of NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N, indicating an enrichment of valence electrons at the top of the valence band. This enrichment facilitates breaking through the forbidden band and achieving a jump in the conduction band. The changes in the band gap are attributed to the enrichment of the band density on the p-orbital of Fe near the Fermi energy level. Both NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N and La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N exhibit asymmetry in the energy band density of the upper and lower spin electrons in the p-orbitals of Fe, thereby inducing asymmetry in the ferromagnetism and the total density of states. Near the Fermi energy level, the pair density of states contributes more for the lower spin electrons. Remarkably, the energy band densities of the lower spin electrons at the top of the valence band and the bottom of the conduction band in La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N contact and merge at the Fermi level, which is not realized in NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N. This is attributed to the defect-induced microscopic changes in the coordination environment around the Fe atoms, suggesting that La and Br co-doping has enabled the material to possess unique semiconducting-metallic properties. Further, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0007" name="bfig0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7c</span></span></a> clearly presents the variation of the energy band density of the upper spin electrons that determines the band gap width. The energy band density of the upper spin electrons of the d-orbital of La is concentrated at the top of the valence band, so that trace La doping after inducing Fe defects makes the top of the valence band of the p-orbital of Fe further close to the Fermi surface. The energy band density of the upper spin electrons in the p-orbital of Br is concentrated near the forbidden band, so that the energy band density of the s-orbital of Br at the O-site doping after inducing Na dual-site defects makes the energy band density of the upper spin electrons in the s-orbital of Na further close to the Fermi surface. Under the synergistic effect of dual-site defects originating from La/Br co-doping, the band gap and energy band structure of NFPP are optimized.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0007"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724006743-gr7.jpg" height="640" alt="Fig 7" aria-describedby="cap0007"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724006743-gr7_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724006743-gr7.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0007"><p id="spara007"><span class="label">Fig. 7</span>. Density functional theory (DFT). PDOS: a) NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N; b) La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N; c) Typical elements. BVEL: d) NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N; e) La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N; f) Na and Fe defects formation energy.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0025">The bond valence energy landscape (BVEL) (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0007" name="bfig0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7d</span></span></a><strong>,</strong> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0007" name="bfig0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">e</span></span></a>) simulated the Na<sup>+</sup> migration paths of NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N and La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N using three-view and three-dimensional diagrams. The Na<sup>+</sup> migration paths of NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N are very narrow, with sharp constrictions or even interruptions at some of the nodes, suggesting that the Na<sup>+</sup> migration is blocked, which is consistent with the lower diffusion coefficients of NFPP. Comparatively, the dual-site defects engineered La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N possesses wider Na<sup>+</sup> migration highways (orange round boxes). The pinning effect of La ensures that the channels at the nodes are not partially closed to the Na<sup>+</sup> migration pathway due to shedding of Na<sup>+</sup>. Br doping-induced Na defects (red boxes) modulate the Na<sup>+</sup> flux in the migration pathway, alleviating the electrostatic interaction between Na<sup>+</sup> and anionic groups (PO<sub>4</sub><sup>3-</sup>, P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub><sup>4-</sup>), thereby reducing the resistance of Na<sup>+</sup> migration. The formation mechanism of dual-site defects is further investigated by DFT calculation, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0007" name="bfig0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7f</span></span></a><strong>.</strong> It has been reported that the Fe2 site and Na2 site have the lowest energies, respectively. Apparently, defects are easily created at both the Fe2 site and Na2 site. Br doping drastically reduces the defect formation energy of the Na2 site from 3.013 eV to 0.316 eV, indicating that Br easily induces the creation of Na defects at the Na2 site. La doping reduces the defect formation energy of the Fe2 site, suggesting that Fe defects are easily induced by La at the Fe2 site. The PDOS, BVEL, and defect formation energy reveal the intrinsic reasons for dual-site defects engineered NFPP's superior capacity and rate performance, which are fully comparable to the reported NFPP cathode materials.</div></section><section id="sec0007"><h2 id="cesectitle0012" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0026">In summary, the Na<sub>4–2</sub><em><sub>x</sub></em>Fe<sub>3–1.5</sub><em><sub>y</sub></em>La<em><sub>y</sub></em>(PO<sub>4-</sub><em><sub>x</sub></em>Br<em><sub>x</sub></em>)<sub>2</sub>P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub> cathode materials with dual-site defects are synthesized by a straightforward mechanical activation method, and the mechanism behind the formation of these defects is revealed. Rietveld refinement, XPS, and density functional theory demonstrate that Fe defects originating from La doping eliminate the inert maricite-NaFePO<sub>4</sub> impurities, while Na defects stemming from Br doping optimize the microchemical valence states. The energy landscape of valence bonds shows that both Fe defects and Na defects alleviate the electrostatic forces between Na<sup>+</sup> ions and the polyanionic backbone, which is essentially crucial for the optimization of Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics. Both <em>in-situ</em> XRD and <em>ex-situ</em> EIS results reveal the outstanding structural stability (with only ∼2.44 % lattice volume change) and crystal reversibility during charging and discharging. As a result, the synthesized dual-site defects-engineered La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N cathode exhibits a reversible discharge specific capacity of 128.2 mAh g<sup>-1</sup> at 0.2 C, outstanding rate performance (55.2 mAh g<sup>-1</sup> at 50 C), as well as impressive cycling stability (93 % capacity retention after 2000 cycles at 10 C). This investigation not only provides a promising NFPP-based cathode material with pure phase, impressive diffusion kinetics of Na<sup>+</sup> and superior electrochemical performance, but also develops a novel dual-site defects engineering strategy for the modification of polyanionic-type cathodes in sodium-ion batteries.</div></section><section id="sec0007a"><h2 id="cesectitle0012a" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0026a"><strong>Wenbin Fei:</strong> Writing – original draft, Investigation, Conceptualization. <strong>Xiaoping Zhang:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Supervision, Resources. <strong>Keyi Sun:</strong> Methodology, Formal analysis. <strong>Yian Wang:</strong> Investigation, Data curation. <strong>Kexin Rao:</strong> Methodology. <strong>Mengting Deng:</strong> Validation, Software. <strong>Chengdong Tao:</strong> Formal analysis. <strong>Ling Wu:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Supervision, Funding acquisition. <strong>Yulei Sui:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Supervision, Project administration, Funding acquisition.</div></section></div><section id="coi0001"><h2 id="cesectitle0013" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0028">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ack0001"><h2 id="cesectitle0014" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgements</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0029">This work was supported by the <span id="gs0001">National Natural Science Foundation of China</span> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">52474331</span></span></a>; href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=The%20nitrogen-doped%20carbon%20coated%20Na4MnV3%20as%20a%20high%20electrochemical%20performance%20cathode%20material%20for%20sodium-ion%20batteries&amp;publication_year=2022&amp;author=Y.%20Wang&amp;author=Q.%20Wang&amp;author=X.%20Ding&amp;author=M.%20Wang&amp;author=Y.%20Xin&amp;author=H.%20Gao" 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (10)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0079642524001944"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Research progress in sodium-iron-phosphate-based cathode materials for cost-effective sodium-ion batteries: Crystal structure, preparation, challenges, strategies, and developments</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Progress in Materials Science</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">Owing to their long cycle life, high energy density, and ecological friendliness, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have been widely used in portable electronic devices and electric vehicles over the past few decades. Nonetheless, the high cost and limited abundance of lithium pose significant obstacles to its widespread use. In response, sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have gained significant attention owing to their abundant sodium resources, similar intercalation chemistry to that of lithium, and low cost. Cathode materials are key components of SIBs, as they significantly impact the electrochemical performance. Among the several cathode candidates, polyanion-type cathode materials are considered the most promising and attractive options for developing SIBs owing to their outstanding electrochemical performance. In this review, the crystal structure classification and synthesis methods of sodium iron phosphate (NaFePO<sub>4</sub>) are comprehensively examined. The issues associated with NaFePO<sub>4</sub> cathode materials for emerging SIBs are also summarized. Furthermore, optimization strategies for enhancing electrochemical performance are discussed, including surface morphology modification, elemental ion substitution, nano-structure architecture, and the probing of innovative structures. Finally, recent research developments and perspectives on NaFePO<sub>4</sub> cathode materials are reviewed. This article provides valuable insights into the development of NaFePO<sub>4</sub> cathode materials for realizing high-performance SIBs for commercialization.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775325003672"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Lanthanum-doped Na&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;Fe&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt;(PO&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;)&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;P&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;O&lt;inf&gt;7&lt;/inf&gt;/C as cathode materials in sodium-ion batteries: Enhanced ion diffusion kinetics and embedded pseudocapacitance</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Journal of Power Sources</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010">The iron-based hybrid polyanionic compound Na<sub>4</sub>Fe<sub>3</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>) (NFPP) is perceived as a potential cathode for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) on account of its high theoretical capacity, resource abundance, nontoxicity and stable framework structure, however, its sodium storage capabilities are hindered by sluggish ionic mobility kinetics. This paper reports the successful synthesis of porous carbon-modified La-doped Na<sub>4</sub>Fe<sub>3</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>) materials using sol-gel and freeze-drying techniques. Na<sub>4</sub>Fe<sub>2.94</sub>La<sub>0.04</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>)/C (NFPP-0.04) showcases remarkable sodium ion mobility, outstanding cycling stability, and exceptionally high discharge specific capacity. These attributes are attributed to the enhancement of embedded pseudocapacitance and electrochemical kinetics through the synergistic effect of lanthanum doping and freeze-drying technology. The NFPP-0.04 achieves a high discharge capacity (128.4 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.2&nbsp;C, 1&nbsp;C&nbsp;=&nbsp;129 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>) and eminent durability (capacity retention of 97.2&nbsp;% after 100 cycles at 0.2&nbsp;C). Furthermore, in situ XRD analysis revealed the exceptional structural stability of NFPP-0.04. Additionally, the correlation of cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves at various scan rates confirms that the charge/discharge mechanism of NFPP-0.04 predominantly relies on embedded pseudocapacitance. This study highlights the feasibility of enhancing the sodium storage kinetics of materials through precise ion doping. Consequently, NFPP-0.04 emerges as a promising candidate for cathodes in sodium-ion batteries (SIBs).</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-2-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2405829725001333"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Advancing high-voltage cathodes for sodium-ion batteries: Challenges, material innovations and future directions</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Energy Storage Materials</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-2-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-2" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara013">High-voltage cathode materials are fundamental to the advancement of sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), offering a sustainable and cost-effective alternative to lithium-ion batteries for energy storage. This review comprehensively examines critical cathode material classes, including polyanionic compounds, layered transition metal oxides, tunnel-structured materials, and Prussian blue analogues. These materials exhibit diverse structural and electrochemical properties, addressing specific challenges such as phase transitions, low conductivity, and structural instability. To overcome these issues, innovative strategies including doping, gradient structures, surface engineering, nano-structuring, and high-entropy material design are developed, offering pathways to enhance stability and capacity retention under high-voltage conditions. Furthermore, advanced characterization techniques and artificial intelligence-driven tools are explored to provide deeper insights into the behaviors of cathode materials, enabling real-time structural analysis and predictive computational modeling for optimization. Integrating experimental and computational approaches not only accelerates the discovery of next-generation cathode materials but also addresses the trade-offs between performance, scalability, and sustainability. By offering a comprehensive framework, this review identifies critical directions for overcoming existing challenges and unlocking the full potential of high-voltage cathode materials for SIBs in grid-scale energy storage and renewable energy applications.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-3-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1021/acssuschemeng.5c01027" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Mitigating Lattice Distortion of Na&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;Fe&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt;(PO&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;)&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;P&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;O&lt;inf&gt;7&lt;/inf&gt; Cathodes at High Voltage for High-Capacity Na-Ion Batteries</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2025, ACS Sustainable Chemistry and Engineering</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-4-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1021/acsnano.4c18614" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Regulating Na/Mn Antisite Defects and Reactivating Anomalous Jahn-Teller Behavior for Na&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;Fe&lt;inf&gt;1.5&lt;/inf&gt;Mn&lt;inf&gt;1.5&lt;/inf&gt;(PO&lt;inf&gt;4&lt;/inf&gt;)&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;(P&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;O&lt;inf&gt;7&lt;/inf&gt;) class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-5-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1002/batt.202500040" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Mg−O Bond Enables Fast Sodium-Ion Insertion/Extraction in id="citing-articles-view-all-btn"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg><span 7.048-9.25 9.41-15.394zM14.32 24.874c4.767-1.526 14.735-2.974 15.152-1.407.824-3.157-13.72-.37-15.153 1.407zm5.28-5.043c2.31 3.237 9.816 7.498 9.788 3.82-.306 2.046-6.66-1.097-8.925-4.164-4.087-5.534-2.39-8.772-1.682-8.732.917.047 1.074 1.307.67 2.442-.173-1.406-.58-2.44-1.224-2.415-1.835.067-1.905 4.46 1.37 9.065z" fill="#f91d0a"></path></svg><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View PDF</span></span></a></div></li><li class="RelatedContentPanelItem u-display-none"><div class="sub-heading u-padding-xs-bottom"><h3 class="related-content-panel-list-entry-outline-padding text-s u-font-serif" id="recommended-articles-article4-title"><a class="anchor u-clamp-2-lines anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775321004407" title="Polyvinylpyrrolidone assisted synthesized ultra-small Na4Fe3(PO4)2(P2O7) particles embedded in 1D carbon nanoribbons with enhanced room and low temperature sodium storage performance"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><span>Polyvinylpyrrolidone assisted synthesized ultra-small Na<sub>4</sub>Fe<sub>3</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>(P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>) particles embedded in 1D carbon nanoribbons with enhanced room and low temperature sodium storage     const pendoData = {"visitor":{"pageName":"SD:product:journal:article","pageType":"CP-CA","pageProduct":"SD","pageLanguage":"en","pageEnvironment":"prod","accessType":"ae:ANON_IP","countryCode":"GB"},"account":{"id":"ae:11279","name":"ae:Imperial College London"},"events":{}};;
    pendoData.events = {

    function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,

        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>
