t(G,F,aa,Z,k,H,I){G=K(G,K(K(n(F,aa,Z),k),I));return K(L(G,H),F)}function e(G){var Z;var F=G.length;var x=F+8;var k=(x-(x%64))/64;var I=(k+1)*16;var aa=Array(I-1);var d=0;var H=0;while(H<F){Z=(H-(H%4))/4;d=(H%4)*8;aa[Z]=(aa[Z]| (G.charCodeAt(H)<<d));H++}Z=(H-(H%4))/4;d=(H%4)*8;aa[Z]=aa[Z]|(128<<d);aa[I-2]=F<<3;aa[I-1]=F>>>29;return aa}function B(x){var k="",F="",G,d;for(d=0;d<=3;d++){G=(x>>>(d*8))&255;F="0"+G.toString(16);k=k+F.substr(F.length-2,2)}return k}function J(k){k=k.replace(/rn/g,"n");var d="";for(var F=0;F<k.length;F++){var x=k.charCodeAt(F);if(x<128){d+=String.fromCharCode(x)}else{if((x>127)&&(x<2048)){d+=String.fromCharCode((x>>6)|192);d+=String.fromCharCode((x&63)|128)}else{d+=String.fromCharCode((x>>12)|224);d+=String.fromCharCode(((x>>6)&63)|128);d+=String.fromCharCode((x&63)|128)}}}return d}var C=Array();var P,h,E,v,g,Y,X,W,V;var S=7,Q=12,N=17,M=22;var A=5,z=9,y=14,w=20;var o=4,m=11,l=16,j=23;var U=6,T=10,R=15,O=21;s=J(s);C=e(s);Y=1732584193;X=4023233417;W=2562383102;V=271733878;for(P=0;P<C.length;P+=16){h=Y;E=X;v=W;g=V;Y=u(Y,X,W,V,C[P+0],S,3614090360);V=u(V,Y,X,W,C[P+1],Q,3905402710);W=u(W,V,Y,X,C[P+2],N,606105819);X=u(X,W,V,Y,C[P+3],M,3250441966);Y=u(Y,X,W,V,C[P+4],S,4118548399);V=u(V,Y,X,W,C[P+5],Q,1200080426);W=u(W,V,Y,X,C[P+6],N,2821735955);X=u(X,W,V,Y,C[P+7],M,4249261313);Y=u(Y,X,W,V,C[P+8],S,1770035416);V=u(V,Y,X,W,C[P+9],Q,2336552879);W=u(W,V,Y,X,C[P+10],N,4294925233);X=u(X,W,V,Y,C[P+11],M,2304563134);Y=u(Y,X,W,V,C[P+12],S,1804603682);V=u(V,Y,X,W,C[P+13],Q,4254626195);W=u(W,V,Y,X,C[P+14],N,2792965006);X=u(X,W,V,Y,C[P+15],M,1236535329);Y=f(Y,X,W,V,C[P+1],A,4129170786);V=f(V,Y,X,W,C[P+6],z,3225465664);W=f(W,V,Y,X,C[P+11],y,643717713);X=f(X,W,V,Y,C[P+0],w,3921069994);Y=f(Y,X,W,V,C[P+5],A,3593408605);V=f(V,Y,X,W,C[P+10],z,38016083);W=f(W,V,Y,X,C[P+15],y,3634488961);X=f(X,W,V,Y,C[P+4],w,3889429448);Y=f(Y,X,W,V,C[P+9],A,568446438);V=f(V,Y,X,W,C[P+14],z,3275163606);W=f(W,V,Y,X,C[P+3],y,4107603335);X=f(X,W,V,Y,C[P+8],w,1163531501);Y=f(Y,X,W,V,C[P+13],A,2850285829);V=f(V,Y,X,W,C[P+2],z,4243563512);W=f(W,V,Y,X,C[P+7],y,1735328473);X=f(X,W,V,Y,C[P+12],w,2368359562);Y=D(Y,X,W,V,C[P+5],o,4294588738);V=D(V,Y,X,W,C[P+8],m,2272392833);W=D(W,V,Y,X,C[P+11],l,1839030562);X=D(X,W,V,Y,C[P+14],j,4259657740);Y=D(Y,X,W,V,C[P+1],o,2763975236);V=D(V,Y,X,W,C[P+4],m,1272893353);W=D(W,V,Y,X,C[P+7],l,4139469664);X=D(X,W,V,Y,C[P+10],j,3200236656);Y=D(Y,X,W,V,C[P+13],o,681279174);V=D(V,Y,X,W,C[P+0],m,3936430074);W=D(W,V,Y,X,C[P+3],l,3572445317);X=D(X,W,V,Y,C[P+6],j,76029189);Y=D(Y,X,W,V,C[P+9],o,3654602809);V=D(V,Y,X,W,C[P+12],m,3873151461);W=D(W,V,Y,X,C[P+15],l,530742520);X=D(X,W,V,Y,C[P+2],j,3299628645);Y=t(Y,X,W,V,C[P+0],U,4096336452);V=t(V,Y,X,W,C[P+7],T,1126891415);W=t(W,V,Y,X,C[P+14],R,2878612391);X=t(X,W,V,Y,C[P+5],O,4237533241);Y=t(Y,X,W,V,C[P+12],U,1700485571);V=t(V,Y,X,W,C[P+3],T,2399980690);W=t(W,V,Y,X,C[P+10],R,4293915773);X=t(X,W,V,Y,C[P+1],O,2240044497);Y=t(Y,X,W,V,C[P+8],U,1873313359);V=t(V,Y,X,W,C[P+15],T,4264355552);W=t(W,V,Y,X,C[P+6],R,2734768916);X=t(X,W,V,Y,C[P+13],O,1309151649);Y=t(Y,X,W,V,C[P+4],U,4149444226);V=t(V,Y,X,W,C[P+11],T,3174756917);W=t(W,V,Y,X,C[P+2],R,718787259);X=t(X,W,V,Y,C[P+9],O,3951481745);Y=K(Y,h);X=K(X,E);W=K(W,v);V=K(V,g)}var i=B(Y)+B(X)+B(W)+B(V);return i.toLowerCase()}
    ,stripProductDelimiters: function(val) {
        if (val) {
            return val.replace(/\;|\||\,/gi, '-');
        }
    }

    ,setCookie: function(name, value, seconds, domain) {
        domain = document.location.hostname;
        var expires = '';
        var expiresNow = '';
        var date = new Date();
        date.setTime(date.getTime() + (-1 * 1000));
        expiresNow = "; expires=" + date.toGMTString();

        if (typeof(seconds) != 'undefined') {
            date.setTime(date.getTime() + (seconds * 1000));
            expires = '; expires=' + date.toGMTString();
        }

        var type = typeof(value);
        type = type.toLowerCase();
        if (type != 'undefined' && type != 'string') {
            value = JSON.stringify(value);
        }

        // fix scoping issues
        // keep writing the old cookie, but make it expire
        document.cookie = name + '=' + value + expiresNow + '; path=/';

        // now just set the right one
        document.cookie = name + '=' + value + expires + '; path=/; domain=' + domain;
    }

    ,getCookie: function(name) {
        name = name + '=';
        var carray = document.cookie.split(';'), value;

        for (var i=0; i<carray.length; i++) {
            var c = carray[i];
            while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
                c = c.substring(1, c.length);
            }
            if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
                value = c.substring(name.length, c.length);
                try {
                    value = JSON.parse(value);
                } catch(ex) {}

                return value;
            }
        }

        return null;
    }

    ,deleteCookie: function(name) {
        this.setCookie(name, '', -1);
        this.setCookie(name, '', -1, document.location.hostname);
    }

    ,mapAdobeVars: function(s) {
        var vars = {
            pageName		: 'Page - Analytics Pagename'
            ,channel		: 'Page - Section Name'
            ,campaign		: 'Campaign - ID'
            ,currencyCode	: 'Page - Currency Code'
            ,purchaseID		: 'Order - ID'
            ,prop1			: 'Visitor - Account ID'
            ,prop2			: 'Page - Product Name'
            ,prop4			: 'Page - Type'
            ,prop6			: 'Search - Type'
            ,prop7			: 'Search - Facet List'
            ,prop8			: 'Search - Feature Used'
            ,prop12			: 'Visitor - User ID'
            ,prop13			: 'Search - Sort Type'
            ,prop14			: 'Page - Load Time'
            ,prop15         : 'Support - Topic Name'
            ,prop16			: 'Page - Business Unit'
            ,prop21			: 'Search - Criteria'
            ,prop24			: 'Page - Language'
            ,prop25			: 'Page - Product Feature'
            ,prop28         : 'Support - Search Criteria'
            ,prop30			: 'Visitor - IP Address'

            ,prop60			: 'Search - Data Form Criteria'
            ,prop63			: 'Page - Extended Page Name'
            ,prop65         : 'Page - Online State'
            ,prop67         : 'Research Networks'
            ,prop40: 'Page - UX Properties'

            ,eVar3			: 'Search - Total Results'
            ,eVar7			: 'Visitor - Account Name'
            ,eVar15			: 'Event - Search Results Click Position'
            ,eVar19			: 'Search - Advanced Criteria'
            ,eVar21			: 'Promo - Clicked ID'
            ,eVar22			: 'Page - Test ID'

            ,eVar156		: 'Event - AutoSuggest Search Selected Term'
            ,eVar162		: 'Event - AutoSuggest Search Category'
            ,eVar163		: 'Event - AutoSuggest Search Details'
            ,eVar33			: 'Visitor - Access Type'

            ,eVar41			: 'Visitor - Industry'
            ,eVar42			: 'Visitor - SIS ID'
            ,eVar43			: 'Page - Error Type'
            ,eVar44			: 'Event - Updated User Fields'
            ,eVar48			: 'Email - Recipient ID'
            ,eVar51			: 'Email - Message ID'
            ,eVar52			: 'Visitor - Department ID'
            ,eVar53			: 'Visitor - Department Name'
            ,eVar60			: 'Search - Within Content Criteria'
            ,eVar61			: 'Search - Within Results Criteria'
            ,eVar62			: 'Search - Result Types'
            ,eVar74			: 'Page - Journal Info'
            ,eVar59			: 'Page - Journal Publisher'
            ,eVar76			: 'Email - Broadlog ID'
            ,eVar78			: 'Visitor - Details'
            ,eVar80         : 'Visitor - Usage Path Info'
            ,eVar102		: 'Form - Name'
            ,eVar103        : 'Event - Conversion Driver'
            ,eVar105        : 'Search - Current Page'
            ,eVar106        : 'Visitor - App Session ID'
            ,eVar107        : 'Page - Secondary Product Name'
            ,eVar117        : 'Search - Database'
            ,eVar126        : 'Page - Environment'
            ,eVar141        : 'Search - Criteria Original'
            ,eVar143        : 'Page - Tabs'
            ,eVar161        : 'Search - Channel'
            ,eVar169        : 'Search - Facet Operation'
            ,eVar173        : 'Search - Details'
            ,eVar174        : 'Campaign - Spredfast ID'
            ,eVar175        : 'Visitor - TMX Device ID'
            ,eVar176        : 'Visitor - TMX Request ID'
            ,eVar148        : 'Visitor - Platform Name'
            ,eVar149        : 'Visitor - Platform ID'
            ,eVar152        : 'Visitor - Product ID'
            ,eVar153        : 'Visitor - Superaccount ID'
            ,eVar154        : 'Visitor - Superaccount Name'
            ,eVar177        : 'Page - Context Domain'
            ,eVar189    : 'Page - Experimentation User Id'
            ,eVar190    : 'Page - Identity User'
            ,eVar199    : 'Page - ID+ Parameters'

            ,list2			: 'Page - Widget Names'
            ,list3			: 'Promo - IDs'
        };

        for (var i in vars) {
            s[i] = s[i] ? s[i] : _satellite.getVar(vars[i]);
        }
    }
};

// async support fallback
(function(w) {
	var eventBuffer = [];
	if(w.appData) {
		if(Array.isArray(w.appData)) {
			eventBuffer = w.appData;
		} else {
			console.error('Elsevier DataLayer "window.appData" must be specified as array');
			return;
		}
    }

	w.appData = [];

	var oldPush = w.appData.push;

	var appDataPush = function() {
        oldPush.apply(w.appData, arguments);
        for(var i=0; i<arguments.length; i++) {
            var data = arguments[i];
            if(data.event) {
                if(data.event == 'pageLoad') {
                    w.pageDataTracker.trackPageLoad(data);
                } else {
                    w.pageDataTracker.trackEvent(data.event, data);
                }
            }
        }
	};

	w.appData.push = appDataPush;
	for(var i=0; i<eventBuffer.length; i++) {
	    var data = eventBuffer[i];
	    w.appData.push(data);
	}
})(window);

</script>
<script>_satellite["_runScript1"](function(event, target, Promise) {
_satellite.logger.log("eventDispatcher: clearing tracking state");try{s.events="",s.linkTrackVars="",s.linkTrackEvents=""}catch(e){_satellite.logger.log("eventDispatcher: s object - could not reset state.")}try{dispatcherData=JSON.parse(event.detail),window.ddqueue=window.ddqueue||[],window.ddqueue.push(dispatcherData),window.eventData=dispatcherData.eventData,window.pageData=dispatcherData.pageData,_satellite.track(dispatcherData.eventName)}catch(e){_satellite.logger.log("eventDispatcher: exception"),_satellite.logger.log(e)}
});</script>
<script>_satellite["_runScript2"](function(event, target, Promise) {
_satellite.logger.log("eventDispatcher: clearing tracking state");try{s.events="",s.linkTrackVars="",s.linkTrackEvents=""}catch(e){_satellite.logger.log("eventDispatcher: s object - could not reset state.")}try{dispatcherData=JSON.parse(event.detail),window.ddqueue=window.ddqueue||[],window.ddqueue.push(dispatcherData),window.eventData=dispatcherData.eventData,window.pageData=dispatcherData.pageData,_satellite.track(dispatcherData.eventName)}catch(e){_satellite.logger.log("eventDispatcher: exception"),_satellite.logger.log(e)}
});</script>

They are usually only set in response to actions made by you which amount to a request for services, such as setting your privacy preferences, logging in or filling in forms. You can set your browser to block or alert you about these cookies, but some parts of the site will not then work. These cookies do not store any personally identifiable information.

class=\"key-dates-help\"><h3 class=\"u-margin-s-bottom u-h4\">Publication milestones</h3><p class=\"u-margin-m-bottom\">The dates displayed for an article provide information on when various publication milestones were reached at the journal that has published the article. Where applicable, activities on preceding journals at which the article was previously under consideration are not shown (for instance submission, revisions, rejection).</p><p class=\"u-margin-xs-bottom\">The publication milestones include:</p><ul class=\"key-dates-help-list u-margin-m-bottom u-padding-s-left\"><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Received</span>: The date the article was originally submitted to the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Revised</span>: The date the most recent revision of the article was submitted to the journal. Dates corresponding to intermediate revisions are not shown.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Accepted</span>: The date the article was accepted for publication in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Available online</span>: The date a version of the article was made available online in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Version of Record</span>: The date the finalized version of the article was made available in the journal.</li></ul><p>More information on publishing policies can be found on the <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/about/policies-and-standards/publishing-ethics\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing Ethics Policies</span></span></a> page. 53 87.78c17.74 0 39.11 4.13 41.08 22.84l.84 9.38h10.04l-.93-10.34C101.88 89.23 83.89 78 53 78S4.11 89.22 1.95 109.73L1.04 120h10.03M53 17.71c-9.72 0-18.24 8.69-18.24 18.59 0 13.67 7.84 23.98 18.24 u-display-none-from-lg u-margin-s-right"><button class="button-link button-link-secondary button-link-icon-left button-link-has-colored-icon" type="button"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 128 128" id="social-popover"><div id="popover-trigger-social-popover"><button class="button-link button-link-secondary u-margin-s-right button-link-icon-left button-link-has-colored-icon" type="button" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="true"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 114 128" height="20" class="icon icon-share"><path d="M90 112c-6.62 0-12-5.38-12-12s5.38-12 12-12 12 5.38 12 12-5.38 70.2c.58-1.98.9-4.04.9-6.2s-.32-4.22-.9-6.2l28.42-15.28C77.56 47.1 83.44 50 90 50c12.14 0 22-9.86 22-22S102.14 6 90 6s-22 9.86-22 22c0 1.98.28 3.9.78 5.72L40.14 49.1C36.12 44.76 30.38 42 24 42 11.86 42 2 51.86 2 64s9.86 22 22 22c6.38 0 12.12-2.76 16.14-7.12l28.64 15.38c-.5 1.84-.78 3.76-.78 5.74 0 12.14 9.86 22 22 22s22-9.86 22-22-9.86-22-22-22z"></path></svg><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Share</span></span></button></div></div></div><div class="ExportCitation u-display-inline-block" id="export-citation"><div class="popover export-citation-popover" id="export-citation-popover"><div id="popover-trigger-export-citation-popover"><button class="button-link button-link-secondary button-link-icon-left button-link-has-colored-icon" type="button" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="true"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 104 128" height="20" class="icon icon-cited-by-66"><path d="M2 58.78V106h44V64H12v-5.22C12 40.28 29.08 32 46 32V22C20.1 22 2 37.12 2 58.78zM102 32V22c-25.9 0-44 15.12-44 36.78V106h44V64H68v-5.22C68 40.28 85.08 32 102 32z"></path></svg><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Cite</span></span></button></div></div></div></div></div><div class="ArticleIdentifierLinks u-margin-xs-bottom text-xs" id="article-identifier-links"><a class="anchor doi anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ensm.2024.103848" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" aria-label="Persistent link using digital object identifier" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ensm.2024.103848</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor rights-and-content anchor-primary" href="https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?publisherName=ELS&amp;contentID=S2405829724006743&amp;orderBeanReset=true" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Get rights and content</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div><div class="LicenseInfo text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author-highlights" id="abs0001"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Highlights</h2><div id="abss0001"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara008"><ul class="list"><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0001">A dual-site defects-engineering strategy is proposed to modify the Na<sub>4</sub>Fe<sub>3</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0002">La doping-induced iron defects eliminate inert phase and broadened the Na<sup>+</sup> channel.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0003">The Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics are improved by Br doping-induced sodium defects.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0004">The dual-site defects-engineered cathode exhibits superior Na-storage performance.</div></span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="abstract author" id="abs0002"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="abss0002"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara009">Na<sub>4</sub>Fe<sub>3</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub> is a prominent polyanionic material widely studied as a cathode for sodium-ion batteries, valued for its stable cycling performance and cost-effectiveness. However, the sluggish diffusion kinetics of Na<sup>+</sup> associated with electrochemically inert NaFePO<sub>4</sub> impurities during synthesis strictly limit the rate performance and energy density of Na<sub>4</sub>Fe<sub>3</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>. In this study, dual-site defects engineered Na<sub>4–2</sub><em><sub>x</sub></em>Fe<sub>3–1.5</sub><em><sub>y</sub></em>La<em><sub>y</sub></em>(PO<sub>4-</sub><em><sub>x</sub></em>Br<em><sub>x</sub></em>)<sub>2</sub>P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub> cathode materials were synthesized using a facile mechanical activation method, by introducing trace amounts of LaBr<sub>3</sub> as additive. Fe defects originating from La doping eliminate the maricite-NaFePO<sub>4</sub> inert impurities and Na defects stemming from Br doping optimize the microchemical valence states and ion transport kinetics. The density functional theory demonstrates that Fe/Na dual-site defects in the lattice of Na<sub>4</sub>Fe<sub>3</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub> reduce band gap and facilitate Na<sup>+</sup> migration passageway, thereby leading to a superior rate capability and stable sodium storage performance. Moreover, the sodium storage mechanism of the dual-site defects engineered Na<sub>4</sub>Fe<sub>3</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub> cathode material is revealed. The optimal dual-site defects engineered cathode sample delivers excellent rate performance (55.2 mAh g<sup>-1</sup> at 50 C) and long cycling stability (capacity retention of 93 % after 2000 cycles at 10 C). This study provides a promising strategy for engineering dual-site defects to synthesize impurities-free Na<sub>4</sub>Fe<sub>3</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub> cathode material with superior electrochemical performance.</div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="abs0003"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="abss0003"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara010">A dual-site defects-engineering strategy is proposed to promotes the Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics of Na<sub>4</sub>Fe<sub>3</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub> and eliminates the electrochemically inert NaFePO<sub>4</sub> impurities during synthesis. Under the synergistic effect of Fe defects and Na defects, the synthesized Na<sub>4–2</sub><em><sub>x</sub></em>Fe<sub>3–1.5</sub><em><sub>y</sub></em>La<em><sub>y</sub></em>(PO<sub>4-</sub><em><sub>x</sub></em>Br<em><sub>x</sub></em>)<sub>2</sub>P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub> cathode exhibits an improved discharge specific capacity, superior rate performance, and impressive cycling stability. <span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0008"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724006743-ga1.jpg" height="244" alt="Image, graphical abstract"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724006743-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (513KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (513KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724006743-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S2405829724006652"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S2405829724006688"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="keys0001" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="key0001" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0002">Na<sub>4</sub>Fe<sub>3</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub></span></div><div id="key0002" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0003">Dual-site defects</span></div><div id="key0003" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0004">Sodium storage mechanism</span></div><div id="key0004" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0005">Impurity elimination</span></div><div id="key0005" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0006">Sodium ion battery</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="sec0001"><h2 id="cesectitle0006" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0006">With the advancement of science and technology, researchers have explored new types of energy storage systems to realize the rational storage and distribution of energy [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0001" name="bbib0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0002" name="bbib0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0003" name="bbib0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0004" name="bbib0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0005" name="bbib0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>]. Although lithium-ion batteries serve as excellent energy storage devices, their development is gradually being limited by resource constraints [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0006" name="bbib0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0007" name="bbib0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0008" name="bbib0008" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0008"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0009" name="bbib0009" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0009"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0010" name="bbib0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a>]. Sodium, which is more abundant in the Earth's crust compared to lithium, is being considered as a potential substitute for large-scale Energy Storage Systems (ESSs) in the future [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0011" name="bbib0011" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0011"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">11</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0012" name="bbib0012" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0012"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">12</span></span></a>]. However, a critical challenge for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) currently is the lack of low-cost and long-life cathode materials [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0013" name="bbib0013" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0013"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0014" name="bbib0014" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0014"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">14</span></span></a>]. Among various cathode materials reported for SIBs, iron-based polyanionic compounds are considered to be suitable for the expected application areas of sodium-ion batteries and have received extensive attention from the academic community [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0015" name="bbib0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">15</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0016" name="bbib0016" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0016"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">16</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0007">In recent years, Na<sub>4</sub>Fe<sub>3</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub> (NFPP), which was firstly reported by Kim et al. in 2012 [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0017" name="bbib0017" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0017"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0019" name="bbib0019" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0019"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>], has aroused significant interest due to its favorable plateau voltage (3.05 V), impressive theoretical specific capacity (1 C = 129 mAh g<sup>-1</sup>) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0020" name="bbib0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20</span></span></a>] and outstanding structural stability (∼4 % volume change during charging and discharging) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0021" name="bbib0021" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0021"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>]. However, the sluggish diffusion kinetics of Na<sup>+</sup> and poor electrical conductivity caused by electrochemically inactive maricite-NaFePO<sub>4</sub> impurities during the preparation process strictly constrain the rate performance and energy density of NFPP [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0022" name="bbib0022" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0022"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">22</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0023" name="bbib0023" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0023"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">23</span></span></a>]. During thermodynamic synthesis, trace iron undergoes excessive oxidation to trivalent iron, resulting in a mismatched lattice structure [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0024" name="bbib0024" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0024"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0025" name="bbib0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0026" name="bbib0026" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0026"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0027" name="bbib0027" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0027"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0028" name="bbib0028" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0028"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[28]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0029" name="bbib0029" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0029"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0030" name="bbib0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a>]. To overcome these issues, various strategies have been proposed to optimize the structure of NFPP, such as element doping, substitution, and surface modification [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0024" name="bbib0024" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0024"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0025" name="bbib0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0026" name="bbib0026" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0026"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0027" name="bbib0027" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0027"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0028" name="bbib0028" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0028"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[28]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0029" name="bbib0029" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0029"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0030" name="bbib0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a>]. For instance, X. Li et al. successfully modified NFPP by introducing Mn<sup>2+</sup> doping and rGO coating, and the Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics and conductivity are ameliorated [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0024" name="bbib0024" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0024"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">24</span></span></a>]. Y. Cao et al. managed to reduce inert impurities by depleting trace levels of Fe [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0022" name="bbib0022" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0022"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">22</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0023" name="bbib0023" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0023"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">23</span></span></a>]. Lately, our research group also developed Ni-substituted NFPP cathode material that partially suppresses the formation of electrochemically inactive maricite-NaFePO<sub>4</sub> impurities [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0031" name="bbib0031" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0031"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">31</span></span></a>]. However, simultaneously addressing all these challenges remains a significant obstacle towards achieving controlled synthesis of NFPP with superior rate performance for stable sodium storage.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0008">In this study, dual-site defects-engineered Na<sub>4–2</sub><em><sub>x</sub></em>Fe<sub>3–1.5</sub><em><sub>y</sub></em>La<em><sub>y</sub></em>(PO<sub>4-</sub><em><sub>x</sub></em>Br<em><sub>x</sub></em>)<sub>2</sub>P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub> (La-Br-NFPP) cathode materials were synthesized with the addition of lanthanum and bromine by a facile mechanical activation method. The doping of the heterovalent lanthanum at the iron site generates iron defects according to the principle of charge conservation, which is beneficial to inhibit low electrochemical activity maricite-NaFePO<sub>4</sub> impurities [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0021" name="bbib0021" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0021"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>]. Additionally, by incorporating heterovalent bromine at the oxygen site, sodium defects can be effectively induced, which can mitigate the electrostatic effect between Na<sup>+</sup> and anionic frameworks, and also widen sodium ions diffusion channels [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0032" name="bbib0032" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0032"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">32</span></span></a>]. Moreover, Fe/Na dual-site defects optimize the lattice structure of NFPP, which reduces band gap and enhances Na<sup>+</sup> migration passageway, thus leading to superior rate capability and stable sodium storage performance with only ∼2.44 % lattice volume change). As a result, the optimum La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N demonstrates an initial discharge capacity of 128.2 mAh g<sup>-1</sup> at 0.2 C (1 C = 129 mAh g<sup>-1</sup>), outstanding rate performance (55.2 mAh g<sup>-1</sup> at 50 C) and excellent long-cycle stability (about 93.0 % capacity retention after 2000 cycles at 10 C). Through the kinetic analysis of the electrode processes and bond valance energy landscape calculation (BVEL), it can be confirmed that La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N possesses an ultra-high Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion rate due to its dual-defect engineering approach. <em>In-situ</em> XRD, <em>ex-situ</em> EIS, structural refinement and density functional theory (DFT) reveal the role of the LaBr<sub>3</sub> in dual site defects and the sodium storage mechanism of La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N.</div></section><section id="sec0002"><h2 id="cesectitle0007" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental section</h2><section id="sec0003"><h3 id="cesectitle0008" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Material synthesis</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0009">Na<sub>4</sub>Fe<sub>3</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N (NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N), Na<sub>4</sub>Fe<sub>2.97</sub>La<sub>0.02</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N (La2-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N), Na<sub>4</sub>Fe<sub>2.94</sub>La<sub>0.04</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N (La4-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N), Na<sub>4</sub>Fe<sub>2.91</sub>La<sub>0.06</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N (La4-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N) were synthesized via a mechanical activation method. Fe(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub>·9H<sub>2</sub>O, La(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub>, NH<sub>4</sub>H<sub>2</sub>PO<sub>4</sub>, and EDTA-2Na were added to a ball milling tank in stoichiometric ratio and milled at a rate of 300 r/min for 12 h After drying, the precursors were sintered in an argon-filled furnace at a heating rate of 3 °C/min for 3 h at 300 °C, and then held at 510 °C for 10 h, to produce LaY-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N (<em>Y</em> = 0, 2, 4, 6) composites. Further, Na<sub>4–2</sub><em><sub>x</sub></em>Fe<sub>2.94</sub>La<sub>0.04</sub>(PO<sub>4-</sub><em><sub>x</sub></em>Br<em><sub>x</sub></em>)<sub>2</sub>P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub> (La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N) was prepared by substituting La(NO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub> with LaBr<sub>3</sub>.</div></section><section id="sec0004"><h3 id="cesectitle0009" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Material characterization</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0010">The samples were analyzed using an Ultima IV powder X-ray diffractometer (XRD) from Rigaku, Japan, which employs Cu Kα radiation and scans from 5° to 90° at 0.02° intervals to characterize their structure and architecture. Raman spectroscopy (LabRAM Soleil) was utilized to analyze the structure of the carbon coatings, with a wavenumber range of 1000–1700 cm⁻<sup>1</sup>. FTIR spectrometer (VERTEX 70+HYPERION 2000) was employed to investigate surface radicals of the synthesized samples. Scanning electron microscopy (Hitachi SU-5000) and transmission electron microscopy (HT7700 &amp; Talos F200X G2) were employed to examine the morphological features. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250XI) was used to analyze the valence states of elements in the composites. Elemental quantitative analysis data were obtained using inductively coupled plasma (iCAPTM Qc).</div></section><section id="sec0005"><h3 id="cesectitle0010" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Electrochemical measurements</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0011">The active material, binder and conductive agent of the electrode were mixed with NMP in the mass ratio of 8:1:1, coated on aluminum foil and then baked in air at 110 °C for 8 h. The dried samples were cut into circular pole pieces, 12 mm in diameter. CR2032 coin cells were assembled in a glove box filled with Ar gas, using homemade Na-sheets as the anode, glass fiber discs as the diaphragm, and 1 M NaClO<sub>4</sub> solution (with 5 % FEC in a mixture of DEC, EC, and DMC in equal volumes (1:1:1)) as the electrolyte. Electrochemical experiments and GITT measurements were performed using the NEWARE battery test system from 4.3 V to 1.8 V vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup>. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy tests were conducted on an electrochemical workstation (CHI660D), employing an AC voltage amplitude of 5 mV and a frequency range from 0.05 Hz to 100 kHz. Multi-scan cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests were carried out using a CHI1000B electrochemical workstation.</div></section></section><section id="sec0006"><h2 id="cesectitle0011" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0012">The schematic of a dual-site defects-engineering strategy is illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1a</span></span></a>. The Fe2 site has the lowest energy state in the lattice of NFPP [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0022" name="bbib0022" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0022"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">22</span></span></a>], and the introduction of the heterovalent element La (103.2pm) creates defects in the Fe2 site, which reduces the probability of forming the inert maricite-NaFePO<sub>4</sub> impurities and allows for broadening of the sodium ion transport channels. Heterovalent doping of Br at the O-site of the PO<sub>4</sub> moiety induces Na defects at the most active Na2-site through charge balance [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0032" name="bbib0032" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0032"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">32</span></span></a>], which alleviates the electrostatic force between Na<sup>+</sup> and the polyanionic backbone, thereby decreasing the resistance to Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion. To definite the Fe/Na defect concentration of the synthesized samples, ICP spectrometer and X-ray diffraction are employed. The iron defect concentration for NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N, La2-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N, La4-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N, and La6-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N are measured to 0, 0.01, 0.02, and 0.03, respectively (<strong>Table S1</strong>). And the sodium defect concentration for La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N is measured to ∼0.04, based on the values of <em>n</em>(Na): <em>n</em>(P).</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0001"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724006743-gr1.jpg" height="650" alt="Fig 1" aria-describedby="cap0001"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724006743-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (2MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724006743-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0001"><p id="spara001"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. Physical phase analysis. a) Crystal structure; b) X-ray diffraction analysis; c) XRD peak intensity comparison; d) Rietveld refinement.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0013">The phase structure of the prepared materials is analyzed by XRD (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1b</span></span></a>). All the samples exhibit similar peak patterns and match well with the NFPP standard card. In particular, a regular leftward shift of the diffraction peaks near 15.9° ((011) crystal plane) and 16.7° ((210) crystal plane) with increasing La doping is observed in the XRD localized magnification images at 14.9–17.4° (<strong>Table S2</strong>). The regular expansion of the lattice is indicated, which is attributed to the larger ionic radius of La<sup>3+</sup> (103.2pm) than that of Fe<sup>2+</sup> (61pm), confirming the successful doping of La into the NFPP lattice. Moreover, after bromine doping into the NFPP sample with the optimal La doping level, a larger left shift of the diffraction peaks is observed, indicating further lattice expansion due to the larger ionic radius of Br<sup>-</sup> (196pm) compared to that of O<sup>2-</sup> (140pm). The lattice distortion induced by La and Br enlarges the Na<sup>+</sup> transport channels, which is beneficial to the enhancement of ionic diffusion kinetics. In addition, it is observed that the diffraction peaks at 32.8° (220) and 33.1° (221) disappear when the amount of La doping reaches 0.04, indicating that proper La doping can reduce the iron concentration by causing iron defects and suppress the generation of maricite-NaFePO<sub>4</sub> impurities. The appearance of new diffraction peaks is observed near 32.3° when the La doping amount reaches 0.06, suggesting that excessive La doping leads to the production of Na<sub>2</sub>FeP<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub> phase [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0021" name="bbib0021" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0021"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>]. In addition, the peak intensity of the main diffraction peaks rises after bromine doping (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1c</span></span></a><strong>, Table S3</strong>), which can be attributed to the partial substitution of the P-O covalent bonding by stronger P-Br bonding, leading to the improved crystallinity [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0032" name="bbib0032" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0032"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">32</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0014">The samples are analyzed quantitatively using Rietveld-refinement (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1d</span></span></a><strong>, Figures S1</strong>). All samples belong to the orthogonal Pn2<sub>1</sub>a space group, in agreement with the reported literature by Kim et al. [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0017" name="bbib0017" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0017"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">17</span></span></a>] It is observed from <strong>Tables S4-S7</strong> that the lattice volume of NFPP varies with Fe and Na defect concentrations, and La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N presents the highest lattice volume (1267.94 Å<sup>3</sup>). Both NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N and La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N samples (<strong>Figures S2, S3</strong>) exhibit a three-dimensional framework structure characterized by the combination of three co-angled FeO<sub>6</sub> octahedra with three PO<sub>4</sub> tetrahedra to form the [Fe<sub>3</sub>P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>13</sub>] unit. This structure extends in the b- and c-directions, forming a pseudo-lamellar arrangement with interconnected [P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>] groups along the a-axis, which results in large main tunnels along the b-axis. Within these tunnels, Na1 and Na4 sites are situated, while Na2 and Na3 sites reside between interlayers [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0021" name="bbib0021" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0021"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>]. The introduction of Br modifies the electron cloud distribution near the P atoms, causing distortion in the PO<sub>4</sub> chemical bonding [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0032" name="bbib0032" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0032"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">32</span></span></a>].This alteration affects the electrostatic attraction between PO<sub>4</sub>, FeO<sub>6</sub>, and Na ions, as well as the oxidation states of transition metals, resulting in an increased lattice volume and grain size for La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N (<strong>Table S8</strong>).</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0015">The structural characteristics are further analyzed by IR spectroscopy (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2a</span></span></a>). The principal IR peaks observed in all samples are within the ranges of 950–1250 cm<sup>-1</sup> and 600–700 cm<sup>-1</sup>, indicating the P-O bending vibration and O-P-O stretching vibration of the PO<sub>4</sub> group, respectively [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0020" name="bbib0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20</span></span></a>]. The IR peaks at approximately 720, 891 and 904 cm<sup>-1</sup> correspond to the symmetric and anti-symmetric P-O-P vibrations within the P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub> group [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0022" name="bbib0022" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0022"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">22</span></span></a>]. In particular, La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N is observed to vibrate uniquely near the cluster of IR peaks of the PO<sub>4</sub> moiety, which is attributed to the doping of Br in the PO<sub>4</sub> moiety rather than the P<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub> moiety (<strong>Figure S4</strong>) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0026" name="bbib0026" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0026"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">26</span></span></a>].The phenomenon is consistent with the results of Rietveld-refinement (<strong>Table S5</strong>). Raman spectroscopy was used to examine the chemical composition of the carbon layers in the prepared samples, and similar Raman spectra (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2b</span></span></a>) and carbon content (<strong>Table S9</strong>) can be observed. Peak splitting of the spectra, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2c</span></span></a>, is being used to calculate the value of <em>I</em><sub>D</sub><em>/I</em><sub>G</sub>, which can be employed to evaluate the disordering state in the carbon. The similar values of <em>I</em><sub>D</sub>/<em>I</em><sub>G</sub> for all samples suggest that La and Br doping have few effects on the carbon layer of the samples.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0002"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724006743-gr2.jpg" height="598" alt="Fig 2" aria-describedby="cap0002"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724006743-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724006743-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0002"><p id="spara002"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. Compositional analysis. a) IR spectra; b) Raman spectra; c) Raman spectral splitting of La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N. XPS spectra of d) Fe 2p for La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N, e) Fe 2p for La4-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N, f) La 3d for La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N, g) Br 3d for La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N, h) C 1sf or La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N, and i) N 1 s for La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0016">The composition and elemental valence of La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N are analyzed using XPS photoelectron spectroscopy (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2d</span></span></a><strong>–</strong><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">i</span></span></a>). In the XPS energy spectrum of Fe 2p (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2d</span></span></a>), the peaks at 711 eV and 726 eV correspond to the Fe 2p1/2 and Fe 2p3/2 orbitals, respectively, indicating that Fe exists in an ortho-divalent state [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0033" name="bbib0033" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0033"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">33</span></span></a>]. In the XPS energy spectrum of La 3d (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2f</span></span></a>), four distinct characteristic energy peaks are observed, indicating the presence of La<sup>3+</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0034" name="bbib0034" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0034"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">34</span></span></a>]. Br 3d5/2 and Br 3d3/2 energy peaks are observed in the XPS energy spectrum of Br 3d (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2 g</span></span></a>), demonstrating the presence of Br<sup>-</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0032" name="bbib0032" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0032"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">32</span></span></a>]. The energy spectrum absorption peaks of C 1 s (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2h</span></span></a>) show the presence of C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">C, C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N and C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="double bond">N, proving that N is doped into the carbon layer [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0035" name="bbib0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">35</span></span></a>]. Pyridine N, pyrrole N, graphitic N, and oxidized N are all existed in the carbon layer (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2i</span></span></a><strong>, Table S11</strong>). It is believed that pyridine nitrogen induces defects in the carbon layer, which provides more active sites for Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0035" name="bbib0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">35</span></span></a>]. And graphitic nitrogen increases the electronic conductivity of the carbon layer by providing additional off-domain π-electrons (<strong>Figure S5</strong>) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0035" name="bbib0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">35</span></span></a>]. Consistent with the report of Li et al. [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0026" name="bbib0026" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0026"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">26</span></span></a>], trace amount of Fe<sup>3+</sup> is also observed in La4-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N and NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N in an orthotrivalent state (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2e</span></span></a><strong>, Figure S6</strong>), which leads to inhomogeneous contraction of part of the lattice, thereby adversely affects the de-embedding of Na<sup>+</sup>. It is worth mentioning that the doping of Br successfully inhibits the generation of Fe<sup>3+</sup> and thus improves the lattice state.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0017">The morphology and elemental distribution of all samples are investigated using SEM, EDS, and HRTEM techniques. The SEM images (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3a</span></span></a><strong>–</strong><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">c</span></span></a><strong>, Figure S7</strong>) show that all the samples are irregularly spherical, with secondary particles from the conductive network formed by crosslinking of the carbon layers, suggesting that neither La doping nor Br doping has a remarkable effect on the morphology. The nanopolycrystalline diffraction rings and typical diffraction points of La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N are observed via SAED (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3d</span></span></a>), corresponding to the (602) and (331) crystal planes, respectively. Primary particles with a diameter of about 300 nm are uniformly encapsulated with an amorphous carbon layer of about 4 nm (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3e</span></span></a><strong>,</strong> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">f</span></span></a>), which resulted from the pyrolysis of EDTA under high temperature. The lattice fringes (0.344 nm) are further measured, corresponding to the (402) crystalline plane (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3 g</span></span></a><strong>,</strong> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">h</span></span></a>). EDS analysis (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3i</span></span></a>) show that Na, Fe, P, O, La, Br, C, N in the material are uniformly distributed without local enrichment or phase segregation, indicating that uniform doping of La and Br is achieved.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0003"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724006743-gr3.jpg" height="469" alt="Fig 3" aria-describedby="cap0003"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724006743-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724006743-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0003"><p id="spara003"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. Morphological analysis. SEM images of a) NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N; b) La4-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N; c) La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N. d) Selected electron area diffraction, e)&amp;f) TEM images, g)&amp;h) Lattice fringing, and i) HAADF-EDS images of La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0018">The electrochemical properties of all synthesized samples are investigated using constant current charge/discharge and cyclic voltammetry. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4a</span></span></a> shows the first charge-discharge curves of all samples. The discharge specific capacities of NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N, La2-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N, La4-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N, and La6-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N are 108.8, 117.6, 126.2, and 122.1 mAh g<sup>-1</sup>, respectively (<strong>Table S12</strong>). The rising trend is attributed to the fact that La doping creates Fe defects and reduces the Fe concentration in the system, which gradually eliminates the electrochemically inert NaFePO<sub>4</sub> phase. However, excessive La doping results in the appearance of Na<sub>2</sub>FeP<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub>, which in turn reduces the discharge capacity. It is noteworthy that La doping significantly affects the overall capacity, primarily by influencing the capacity of the platform region (<strong>Table S12</strong>). Furthermore, it is observed that the initial charge-discharge curve of La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N reaches the plateau phase later compared to the other samples. This delay is attributed to the bromine doping, which effectively eliminates the trace amount of Fe<sup>3+</sup> produced during synthesis. The irreversible trauma caused by the inhomogeneous change in the lattice volume during the small-current activation of the cell can be mitigated [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0026" name="bbib0026" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0026"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">26</span></span></a>]. The initial-discharge specific capacity of La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N reaches a surprising 128.2 mAh g<sup>-1</sup>, and its discharge curve plateau voltage is slightly higher than that of other samples, which results from the induced effect of Br. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4b</span></span></a> displays CV curves at a scan rate of 0.05 mV s<sup>-1</sup> within the potential window of 2.0–4.3 V (vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup>). All samples exhibit two pairs of typical redox peaks (at 2.95/2.88 V and 3.23/3.20 V), along with multiple weak redox peaks throughout the voltage range, corresponding to sodium ion insertion/extraction processes at various sites [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0017" name="bbib0017" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0017"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">17</span></span></a>]. The peak differences between two pairs of typical redox peaks of NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N and La4-Br-NFPP@C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">N are compared. It is found that Δ<em>E</em><sub>1</sub> &lt; Δ<em>E</em><sub>2</sub> and Δ<em>E</em><sub>3</sub> &lt; Δ<em>E</em><sub>4</sub>, indicating that the degree of polarization of the modified samples is decreased. Notably, both La doping and Br doping elevate the peak currents, showing the enhanced reactivity.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0004"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724006743-gr4.jpg" height="692" alt="Fig 4" aria-describedby="cap0004"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724006743-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (2MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2405829724006743-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0004"><p id="spara004"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. Electrochemical analysis. a) First cycle charge-discharge curve; b) Cyclic voltammetry curve; c) Rate performance.
